title: Smart Blinds

content:
I wanted an automated blind solution that wouldn’t rely on cloud services or expensive commercial products. By repurposing an IKEA roller shades and designing my own controller system, I was able to build a cheap local solution.
Hardware The smart blind has 4 main components, a 28BYJ-48 stepper motor, a ULN2003 stepper motor driver board, a esp32 as the micro controller, and of course the IKEA roller shade. I chose these because they were very cheap off of Amazon or Aliexpress and because the ULN2003 was supported by Esphome’s stepper component which I was planning on using to program the esp32.
3D-Printed Case To mount and house the motor and eletronics I designed a 3d printed case in Fusion360. This was my first time cading gears so it took me a bit to get the correct gear ration that would allow the motor to have enough torque to raise the blinds without skipping. After that it was just a matter of blocking out where each component would go and build the case around them.
Wiring The wiring for the ULN2003 was rather straight forward and only needed 4 wires connected to the esp32 and then power and ground for both the driver and esp32
Software To test that everything was working I wrote a quick arduino program to spin the motor in both directions for a few seconds. After confirming my wiring was correct and it all worked I started to write the Esphome code. In the process of writing my code I found that RoadKillUK had already done almost exactly what I wanted and published it to Github. I had to modify it slightly to work with an esp32 but it was oretty much perfect.
Usage/Improvements I’ve been running the blind for a little over a year now and have had no issue with it so far. There are a few things that I would change if I made a second version. First, the blinds are slow, they take over a minuet to raise/lower about 3 feet. Second, the stepper motor loses its memory of the blind position if it loses power and will need to be re-homed.
summary: Cheap, simple and effective smart blinds made from and old IKEA roller shades and a few electronic components.

title: “Smart Blinds” date: “2025-01-01” description: “Affordable, fully local smart blinds built from IKEA roller shades and simple electronics.” summary: “A reliable, cloud-free smart blind system using ESP32, ESPHome, and 3D-printed components.” tags: [“esphome”, “esp32”, “home assistant”, “iot”, “3d-printing”] categories: [“Smart Home”, “Projects”] I wanted an automated blind solution that wouldn’t rely on cloud services or expensive commercial products. By repurposing an IKEA roller shade and designing my own control system, I built a low-cost, fully local smart blind solution.
Hardware The smart blind consists of four main components:
28BYJ-48 stepper motor ULN2003 stepper motor driver board ESP32 microcontroller IKEA roller shade These parts were chosen for their affordability and easy availability from vendors like Amazon and Aliexpress. ESPHome’s built-in stepper support for the ULN2003 made integration straightforward with the ESP32.
3D-Printed Enclosure To mount and house the motor and electronics, I designed a 3D-printed case in Fusion 360. This was my first time designing functional gears, and after some iteration I determined the gear ratio required to provide enough torque for the blinds to operate smoothly without skipping. Once the gearing was finalized, I modeled mounting points for all components to create a compact, purpose-built enclosure.
Wiring The wiring is simple:
Four control wires connect the ESP32 to the ULN2003 board. Separate power and ground lines supply both the driver and the ESP32. Software For initial hardware testing, I wrote a basic Arduino sketch to verify motor direction and wiring. Once validated, I transitioned to ESPHome for full firmware development. During this process, I discovered that RoadKillUK had published a highly relevant GitHub project, which served as a strong foundation. I adapted the code for ESP32 compatibility and made a few adjustments to suit my setup.
Usage & Future Improvements The blind has been operating reliably for over a year. A few areas for potential improvement if I build a second version:
Speed: The current setup takes just over one minute to raise or lower ~3 feet of blinds. A more powerful motor could improve cycle time. Position Retention: Since stepper motors have no absolute position awareness, the system loses track of blind position if power is lost. Adding sensors or non-volatile position storage would solve this.
summary: Cheap, simple and effective smart blinds made from and old IKEA roller shades and a few electronic components.
